licence_overview:
If you make copies of articles and extracts from books, magazines, journals and digital titles protected by copyright, you need a business licence from the Copyright Licensing Agency (CLA).

Making copies includes photocopying, faxing, scanning and emailing.

##Conditions

Different licences are available for different business sectors. These include:

* hotels licence – for hotels and conference centres that make copies available for clients
* copyshops licence – for shops that provide a photocopying service
* document delivery licence – for businesses supplying documents to clients
* press cuttings agency licence – for businesses providing print or electronic clippings to clients
* law licence – for law firms and barristers chambers
* pharmaceutical licence – for pharmaceutical, healthcare and biotech companies
* business licence – for other businesses that make copies of copyrighted material


There are also licences available for schools and further and higher education establishments.

##How to apply

You can apply for a licence on the [CLA website.](http://www.cla.co.uk/ "Copyright Licensing Agency"){:rel="external"}

Licence fees are paid annually, and fees and conditions vary depending on the type of licence you apply for.

##Penalties

If you make copies of copyright material without a licence, you're infringing copyright and can be sued for damages.

If you don't pay the licence fee or comply with any other licence conditions, the CLA may suspend or terminate the licence.

^Certain works and categories of material – such as printed music, newspapers and maps – are excluded from all CLA licences. A list of [excluded categories and works is available on the CLA website.](http://www.cla.co.uk/licences/excluded_works/excluded_categories_works "excluded categories and works"){:rel="external"} If you wish to make copies of excluded works, you should contact the rightsholder directly for permission to do so.^

*[CLA]: Copyright Licensing Agency
